_exec_summary.SummaryText:
cility emergency response plans are coordinated with the fire departments and the Delaware County LEPC.  The Boothwyn Fire Department is aware of the system, available protection systems (site fire extinguishers, emergency shut-off devices) and Emergency Response Procedures at the facility.  The Twin Oaks Facility is a non-responding facility.

The Terminal is new, and has not had any accidental releases during the past five years that meet the criteria for an accidental release as discussed in 40 CFR 68.42.
In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Energy Transfer Marketing & Terminals looks for and seeks employee input on process safety improvements.  Additionally, the Boothwyn Fire Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills which involve potential releases.   The contract company that performs the transload operations at the facility is working to improve its training program.
With these objectives in mind, the Risk Management Plan has been developed to provide information regarding the management of the risks associated with the flammable substance storage process. Above all, ETM&T stresses its commitment to ensuring a safe working environment for employees, visitors and the community.

Safety at the Facility depends on the
manner in which flammable substances are handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the
processes. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees and contractors which reinforces the safety policies and
procedures of the Facility. Programs have been established to help prevent any accidental releases and to train personnel for
emergency response in the event of a release.  NOTE: This facility IS NOT a responding facility.
ETM&T has implemented safety precautions and procedures designed to prevent and mitigate catastrophic releases. ETM&T has active operating, maintenance, training and inspection procedures. 

ETM&T's management is committed to the following:
- Preventing accidents;
- Training our employees in correct response procedures in the event of an accident;
- Participating in community emergency preparedness;
- Addressing any citizen concerns by fully explaining potential hazards associated with ETM&T operations and all steps being taken
to prevent and mitigate accidents; and
- Being a good corporate citizen in Delaware County

Twin Oaks Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119) along with its fourteen (14) compliance elements, and all applicable state and local laws and regulations.  The Butane system is designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58, manufacturer's instructions and Energy Transfer specifications.  

In the event of an emergency involving the Twin Oaks Terminal's Butane system, it is the policy of the facility to initially contact the Boothwyn Fire Department and request their assistance.  The facility has no trained fire brigade or hazardous material response team, but outside services may be called in to assist.  The fa

Energy Transfer Marketing & Terminals
Twin Oaks Terminal
RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Energy Transfer Marketing & Terminals  (ETM&T) Twin Oaks Facility, hereafter referred to as the Facility, is a refined petroleum
product storage and distribution facility in Delaware County, PA.  A new butane system was constructed in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA Code) #58 for Liquified Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is the facility's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws/codes.

This Risk Management Program (RMP) covers the butane system only, including the butane offload station, butane storage tank (60,000gal), butane transfer pump, and associated butane piping. 

Two requirements of this section specifically apply to operations at the Facility:
1. Purpose and General Duty Clause - The essence of the general duty clause is that an owner/operator that stores and uses hazardous chemicals in any quantity has a fundamental obligation to ensure a safe operation and to have plans in place in the event of an accident to appropriately manage the situation.
ETM&T is committed to ensuring the safe operation of the Facility, as well as all of its other operations, to ensure a safe workplace for employees and a safe location for neighbors in the community. ETM&T has procedures in place to prevent accidents and is committed to emergency preparedness both for the Facility and community-wide and coordinates with the Boothwyn Fire Department.

2. Risk Management Plan - The primary function of the Facility is to act as a flammable liquid storage and distribution facility. Due to
the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human
exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community.
The Facility is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health.
